skill.name: k8s-manifest-generator
skill.description: Create production-ready Kubernetes manifests for Deployments, Services, ConfigMaps, and Secrets following best practices and security standards. Use when generating Kubernetes YAML manifests, creating K8s resources, or implementing production-grade Kubernetes configurations.
skill.summary: Create production-ready Kubernetes manifests for Deployments, Services, ConfigMaps, and Secrets foll...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation and YAML template skill. No executable code is present. The skill provides guided templates and best practices for Kubernetes manifests. All static findings are false positives: backticks in markdown are code formatting, not command execution; embedded scripts in YAML are template examples, not executable code; cryptographic mentions are documentation references, not actual weak crypto usage.

content.value_statement: Creating Kubernetes manifests requires understanding many fields and best practices. This skill provides guided templates and security-focused examples for Deployments, Services, ConfigMaps, and Secrets.
actual_capabilities: Creates Deployment manifests with probes, resource limits, and security context
Creates Service templates for ClusterIP, LoadBalancer, NodePort, and headless types
Creates ConfigMap templates for key-value pairs, files, JSON, and scripts
Provides guidance for Secrets and PersistentVolumeClaims with security notes
Lists validation and troubleshooting steps using kubectl dry-run and lint tools
limitations: Does not apply manifests to a cluster
Does not generate Helm charts or Kustomize overlays
Does not validate against live cluster state

use_cases.title: Standardize app manifests
use_cases.description: Create consistent Deployment and Service YAML with security and resource settings.

use_cases.title: Bootstrap new service
use_cases.description: Draft manifests for a new API with ConfigMap, Secret, and basic networking.

use_cases.title: Review YAML quality
use_cases.description: Check team manifests against recommended probes, labels, and security context.

prompt_templates.title: Basic web app
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a Deployment and ClusterIP Service for app web-api using image repo/web:1.2.3, port 8080, and namespace dev.

prompt_templates.title: Config and secrets
prompt_templates.prompt: Create manifests for app billing with a ConfigMap for settings, a Secret reference for credentials, a Deployment, and a Service.

prompt_templates.title: Stateful storage
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Deployment and PersistentVolumeClaim for app reports with 20Gi storage and mount it at /var/lib/app.

prompt_templates.title: Hardened production
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate production manifests with non-root security context, read-only filesystem, resource limits, and health probes for app payments.

output_examples.input: Create production manifests for a payments API using image registry/payments:2.1.0, port 8080, and external access.
output: Deployment with three replicas, resource limits, and liveness and readiness probes
ConfigMap and Secret references wired into the Deployment
Security context set to non-root with dropped capabilities

output_examples.input: Create a ConfigMap with nginx configuration for a web server.
output: ConfigMap named web-nginx-config with nginx.conf content
Example nginx.conf with worker processes, log paths, and proxy settings
Instructions for mounting as a volume or exposing as environment variables

best_practices: Provide exact image tags and resource limits in your request
Specify ports, protocols, and exposure type clearly
Describe ConfigMap and Secret requirements explicitly
anti_patterns: Requesting secrets to be placed in plain text in manifests
Using :latest image tags in production deployments
Omitting health probes and security context settings

faq.question: Which Kubernetes versions are supported?
faq.answer: Templates use stable APIs and should work on most current Kubernetes clusters from 1.19 onwards.

faq.question: Are there limits on manifest size or complexity?
faq.answer: No enforced limits, but very large manifests may need manual organization into separate files.

faq.question: Can I use this with Helm or Kustomize?
faq.answer: Yes, but you must adapt the YAML into charts or overlays manually.

faq.question: Does the skill access or store my data?
faq.answer: No, it provides guidance and templates only within the chat session.

faq.question: What if kubectl validation fails?
faq.answer: Use the dry-run and lint steps listed in the skill to pinpoint missing fields or errors.

faq.question: How is this different from a generator tool?
faq.answer: It focuses on best practice guidance, not automated scaffolding or cluster actions.
